set.p: The Scene, [A ship at sea and] an uninhabited IslandDuring the early modern period, knowledge of the world was expanding greatly. It is likely, given the plot of the tale, that the fictional Island Prospero is stranded on is somewhere in the Mediterranean sea. Throughout the play, you will note references to many places across the globe, including Tunisia, Algeria, the Island of Bermuda, and "Arabia." By 1611, when The Tempest was first performed, England had established colonies in the Americas; the Spanish and Portuguese were the most powerful imperial force in Western Europe, until the 1588 defeat of the Spanish Armada, which marked the rise of the early British Empire. The 16th and 17th centuries are often thought of as an age of exploration; explorers traveled the world, bringing back strange objects and stories to spur scientific discovery and commerce, including the traffic in human beings. People during Shakespeare’s time lived during an era that also saw the wide dissemination of maps helped by the invention of the printing press. Through cartography, people could visually comprehend the geographical layout of lands familiar and new. To learn more about exploration and map-making in the early modern period, see the Folger Shakespeare Library's exhibition site, "Mapping Early Modern Worlds. .

div.head: Act I, Scene I.
div.stage: A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning In 1611, when Shakespeare's The Tempest was first performed, theatres used a mechanism known as a thunder machine, which was essentially a long wooden box balanced like a seesaw, containing a large cannon ball that when rolled around produced a loud noise resembling thunder. To create the effect of lightening, stage hands would prepare powdered resin which would be thrown onto a flame. Lighting a firecracker attached to a wire extending from the roof of the stage to the floor would create the illusion of a lightening bolt ("Special Effects").. Enter a Ship-master and a Boatswain

l.note: Pronounced "bosun," a boatswain is the person who manages the crew of a ship and the ship's equipment (OED n.1).

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Here, master: what cheer?

sp.speaker: Master
sp.l: Good, speak to the mariners: fall to't, yarelyNow archaic, yarely derives from the Old English and means quick or nimble action (OED adv).,
or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts!
yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the

master's whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy windHere, the boatswain is directly addressing the tempest, challenging it to rage until it is out of wind, possibly in an attempt to encourage the men on deck to remain strong.,
if room enough!

div.stage: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, Gonzalo, and others

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Good boatswain, have care. Where's the master?

Play the menAccording to the OED (I.1), play was used as an intransitive verb in the 1400s, meaning to engage something or someone in activity. Here, Alonso is seen to be commanding the boatswain to put his crew to work..

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I pray now, keep below.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Where is the master, boatswain?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your
cabins: you do assist the storm.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Nay, good, be patient.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers
for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: None that I more love than myself. You are a
counsellor; if you can command these elements to
silence, and work the peace of the present, we will
not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you
cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make
yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of
the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Out
of our way, I say.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he

hath no drowning markGonzalo takes comfort from his belief that the boatswain's destiny in death is fated for the gallows (death by hanging), which disqualifies him for a death caused by drowning. upon him; his complexion is
perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his
hanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable,
for our own doth little advantage. If he be not
born to be hanged, our case is miserable.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring
her to try with main-course.
A plague upon this howling! they are louder than
the weather or our office.
Yet again! what do you here? Shall we give o'er
and drown? Have you a mind to sink?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous,
incharitable dog!

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Work you then.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker!
We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were
no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an

unstanched wenchGonzalo is comparing the ship to "an / unstanched wench." According to Shakespeare Navigator, which draws on the OED definition of "staunch," calling the boat an "unstanched wench" may be comparing the boat to a woman (a "wench") on her menstrual cycle. However, the verb "stanch" also suggests satisfying a desire (OED v3a), and it derives from the Old French that also means to make a ship watertight..

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two coursesThe Boatswain calls for the ship to be directed "two courses off to / sea." According to the OED, "two courses" has a specific nautical meaning, referring to the points on the compass where the ship is directed (course, n. 12a-b). off to
sea again; lay her off.

sp.speaker: Mariners
sp.l: All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: What, must our mouths be coldAccording to the Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest, the boatswain is wondering if, even if after all his efforts, the sailors must drown, or have their mouths become cold from drowning.?

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: The king and prince at prayers! let's assist them,
For our case is as theirs.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I'm out of patience.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:
This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning

The washing of ten tidesThe washing of a tide is the act of sea water flowing up the shore during a high tide (OED, wash, III.12b). The Arden edition of The Tempest notes that pirates would be condemned to hang at the shore for the length of three tides. Antonio here is extending that length of time for the boatswain, whom he imagines would "lie drowning / [for the] washing of ten tides."!

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: He'll be hang'd yet,
Though every drop of water swear against it
And gape at widest to glut him.

div.stage: A confused noise within: 'Mercy on us!'-- 'We split The ship is splitting in half., we split!'--'Farewell, my wife and children!'-- 'Farewell, brother!'--'We split, we split, we split!'

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Let's all sink with the king.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Let's take leave of him.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an
acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any
thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain
die a dry death.

div.head: Scene II. [The island. Before Prospero's cell.]

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: If by your art, my dearest fatherIt is often thought that Prospero was modeled by Shakespeare on John Dee, a well-known polymath, magus, and advisor to Queen Elizabeth I. According to the British Library, a magus someone who "understands the cosmos and man's place in it [sic]" through knowledge and experimentation in fields such as chemistry (then alchemy), mathematics, astrology, and hermetic studies of religion and culture. A "controversial figure" and force of both good and evil, the magus sought to attain ultimate wisdom about the working of the universe. The image included here, from the British Library, shows (right to left) Dee’s spirit mirror showstone, a crystal ball, mystically engraved wax discs, a wooden case, and an engraved gold disc illustrating a vision of Dee’s colleague, Edward Kelley. Dee's 'showstone' was a reflective piece of volcanic ash he would use to conjure and converse with angels, recording his conversations into his ‘angelic diaries’. As an advisor to Queen Elizabeth I, Dee advocated for imperial expansion into the New World. To learn more about Dee's advocacy of the British Empire in the Atlantic, see Glyn Parry's scholarly article, "John Dee and the Elizabethan British Empire in Its European Context.", you have
Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitchMiranda here imagines the stormy sky raining "stinking pitch" instead of water. Pitch is a resin commonly used for waterproofing boats.,

But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheekThe welkin is a poetic and now archaic term referring to the sky. Miranda uses figurative language to describe the the height of the waves, which "[mount or rise] to the welkin's cheek.",
Dashes the fireThe lightening. out. O, I have suffered
With those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel,
Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her,
Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knock
Against my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.
Had I been any god of power, I would
Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere
It should the good ship so have swallow'd and
The fraughting souls within her.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: No more amazement: tell your piteous heart
There's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: I have done nothing but in care of thee,
Of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter, who
Art ignorant of what thou art, nought knowing
Of whence I am, nor that I am more better
Than Prospero, master of a full poor cellA very small or humble dwelling,
And thy no greater father.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Did never meddle with my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand,
And pluck my magic garment from me. So:
Lie there, my art.Prospero is speaking to his robe, calling it his "art," and suggesting to us that the robe is lain down on some surface by Miranda.. Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.
The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touch'd
The very virtue of compassion in thee,
I have with such provision in mine art
So safely ordered that there is no soul--
No, not so much perdition as an hair
BetidBefell or happened to (OED). to any creature in the vessel
Which thou heard'st cry, which thou saw'st sink. Sit down;
For thou must now know farther.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Begun to tell me what I am, but stopp'd
And left me to a bootless inquisitionIneffective questioning (OED).,
Concluding 'stay: not yet.'

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: The very minute bids thee ope thine ear;
Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
A time before we came unto this cell?
I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not
Out three years old.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: By what? by any other house or person?
Of any thing the image tell me that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysmAn immense depth, a chasm which seems to have no end (OED) of time?
If thou remember'st aught ereAught is an archaic adverb which means "to any extent, in any respect, at all"(OED C.1), and 'ere' means before or formerly (OED 4.a). thou camest here,
How thou camest here thou mayst.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,
Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
A prince of power.

l.hi: Sir, are not you my father?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and
She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father
Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir
And princess no worse issued.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: What foul play had we, that we came from thence?
Or blessed was't we did?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence,
But blessedly holpThis is the past participle of the word "help," spelled this way from the 14th to the 17th century (OED). hither.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: To think o' the teenNow rarely used, teen is a noun that refers to suffering or pain (OED n. 2a). that I have turn'd you to,
Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio--
I pray thee, mark me--that a brother should
Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself
Of all the world I loved and to him put
The manage of my state; as at that time
Through all the signories A historical term referring to governing bodies or assemblies specifically of an Italian state (OED n, 5). it was the first
And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed
In dignity, and for the liberal arts
Without a parallel; those being all my study,
The government I cast upon my brother
And to my state grew stranger, being transported
And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle--
Dost thou attend me?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Being once perfected how to grant suits,
How to deny them, who to advance and who
To trash for over-topping, new created
The creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em,
Or else new form'd 'em; having both the key
Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state
To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was
The ivy which had hid my princely trunk,
And suck'd my verdure According to the OED, this refers to the freshness of a flourishing green plant. out on't. Thou attend'st not.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: O, good sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
With that which, but by being so retired,
O'er-prized all popular rate, in my false brother
Awaked an evil nature; and my trust,
Like a good parent, did beget of him
A falsehood in its contrary as great
As my trust was; which had indeed no limit,
A confidence sans bound. He being thus lorded,
Not only with what my revenue yielded,
But what my power might else exact, like one
Who having into truth, by telling of it,
Made such a sinner of his memory,
To credit his own lie, he did believe
He was indeed the duke; out o' the substitution
And executing the outward face of royalty,
With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing--
Dost thou hear?

l.hi: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: To have no screen between this part he play'd
And him he play'd it for, he needs will be
Absolute Milan. Me, poor man, my library
Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties
He thinks me now incapable; confederates--
So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples
To give him annual tribute, do him homage,
Subject his coronet to his crown and bend
The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!--
To most ignobleAccording to the OED, ignoble is defined as being dishonorable in terms of character or intent. stooping.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Mark his condition and the event; then tell me
If this might be a brother.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: To think but nobly of my grandmother:
Good wombs have borne bad sons.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: The King of Naples, being an enemy
To me inveterate Entrenched, long-standing, persistent, with the suggestion of disease (OED)., hearkens my brother's suit;
Which was, that he, in lieu o' the premises
Of homage and I know not how much tribute,
Should presently extirpate me and mine
Out of the dukedom and confer fair Milan
With all the honours on my brother: whereon,
A treacherous army levied, one midnight
Fated to the purpose did Antonio open
The gates of Milan, and, i' the dead of darkness,
The ministers for the purpose hurried thence
Me and thy crying self.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: I, not remembering how I cried out then,
Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint
That wrings mine eyes to't.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Hear a little further
And then I'll bring thee to the present business
Which now's upon's; without the which this story
Were most impertinent.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: That hour destroy us?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst An archaic past tense of the verb "to dare" (OED). not,
So dear the love my people bore me, nor set
A mark so bloody on the business, but
With colours fairer painted their foul ends.
In few, they hurried us aboard a bark]A bark is a small boat.,
Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared
A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd,
Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats
Instinctively had quit it: there they hoist us,
To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh
To the winds whose pity, sighing back again,
Did us but loving wrong.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Was I then to you!

sp.speaker: Prospero

l.hi: O, a cherubim A cherub is a biblical angel, with a related sense common in the early 17th century that also means a beloved woman (OED n. 5b).

sp.l: Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile.
Infused with a fortitude from heaven,
When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt,
Under my burthenAn alternative spelling of burden. groan'd; which raised in me
An undergoing stomach, to bear up
Against what should ensue.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: By Providence divine.
Some food we had and some fresh water that
A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,
Out of his charity, being then appointed
Master of this design, did give us, with
Rich garments, linens, stuffs and necessaries,
Which since have steaded much; so, of his gentleness,
Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd me
From mine own library with volumes that
I prize above my dukedom.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: But ever see that man!

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Now I arise:
Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.
Here in this island we arrived; and here
Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit
Than other princesses can that have more time
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir,
For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason
For raising this sea-storm?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune,
Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies
Brought to this shore; and by my presciencePrescience is both a quality attributed to God and the characteristic of foresight that a human might possess (OED).
I find my zenithA term from astronomy, the zenith is the highest point the sun or moon reaches in the sky (OED). doth depend upon
A most auspicious star, whose influence
If now I court not but omit, my fortunes
Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions:
Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness,
And give it wayThe Arden edition of The Tempest glosses this as "succumb to it." Prospero is commanding Miranda to fall asleep.: I know thou canst not choose.
Come away, servant, come. I am ready now.
Approach, my Ariel, come.

stage.note: After Miranda falls asleep, Prospero is typically understood to put his magical robe back on as Ariel comes onto the stage. The image here, an engraving after Henry Fusili, shows a late 18th century rendition of Miranda, Prospero, Caliban, and the airy spirit Ariel (Metropolitan Museum of Art).

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I come
To answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly,
To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride
On the curl'd clouds, to thy strong bidding task
Ariel and all his quality.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak,
Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,
I flamed amazement: sometime I'ld divide,
And burn in many places; on the topmast,
The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly,

Then meet and join. Jove's lightningsJove, more famously known as Jupiter, is the most powerful Roman God and is known to overthrow his enemies using his bolt of lightening. His Greek equivalent is Zeus. , the precursors
O' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary
And sight-outrunning were not; the fire and cracks
Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble,
Yea, his dread trident shake.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil
Would not infect his reason?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: But felt a fever of the mad and play'd
Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,
Then all afire with me: the king's son, Ferdinand,
With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,--
Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty
And all the devils are here.'

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: But was not this nighAn old fashioned way of saying nearby or almost (OED). shore?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: But are they, Ariel, safe?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: On their sustaining garments not a blemish,
But fresher than before: and, as thou badest me,
In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
The king's son have I landed by himself;
Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
In an odd angle of the isle and sitting,
His arms in this sad knotSleeping crossed armed (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest).

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: The mariners say how thou hast disposed
And all the rest o' the fleet.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once
Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew

From the still-vex'd BermoothesThe Island of Bermuda was devoid of any habitation by indigenous groups before it was discovered by accident by the Spanish sailor Juan Bermúdez in 1503. A flotilla from England, includng the Sea Venture, was shipwrecked here on their way to restock the Jamestown Colony in Virginia (Virginia was named after Elizabeth I, the "Virgin Queen," and Jamestown, after King James I). The wreck of the Sea Venture in 1609, is thought to be a contemporary inspiration for The Tempest. After almost a year, the crew was largely able to leave the Island with ships they built during that time. The Island wasn’t colonized until the seventeenth century, after the crew of the Sea Venture returned to England with their tale. Enslaved people were first brought to the Island in 1617. The image included here shows a 17th century map of the Island of Bermuda by Willem Janszoon Blaeu, from the Norman B. Leventhal Map Center. The mariners all under hatches stow'd;
Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour,
I have left asleep; and for the rest o' the fleet
Which I dispersed, they all have met again
And are upon the Mediterranean flote,
Bound sadly home for Naples,
Supposing that they saw the king's ship wreck'd
And his great person perish.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work.
What is the time o' the day?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: At least two glassesTwo hourglasses past midday would be 2 p.m. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest) . The time 'twixt six and nowWhatever Prospero is planning must happen between 2 and 6 p.m. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest). It is important to keep in mind that in Elizabethan England, plays would have typically been performed in the afternoon. The action of the play roughly corresponds to the duratioon of the play being acted.
Must by us both be spent most preciously.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,
Let me remember thee what thou hast promised,
Which is not yet perform'd me.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: What is't thou canst demand?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Before the time be out? no more!

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Remember I have done thee worthy service;
Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served
Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise
To bate me a full year.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: From what a torment I did free thee?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze
Of the salt deep,
To run upon the sharp wind of the north,
To do me business in the veins o' the earth
When it is baked with frost.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot
The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy
Was grown into a hoop As a circular band, the witch Sycorax is mentioned to have procured a hunch with age. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest)? hast thou forgot her?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: No, sir.

l.hi: Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Sir, in ArgierSycorax seems to have been born in Argier or Algiers, the capital and chief sea port of Algeria in North Africa, on the Mediterranean coast. Invaded throughout its history, Algiers rose to prominence under the Berber dynasties in the 10th century. Algiers became became home to many Muslim and Jewish refugees escaping Spain in the begining of the 16th century. At the time The Tempest was written, Algiers was under Ottoman rule, and it became associated with piracy (Britannica). The image included here, from the Library of Congress’ first volume of Civitates Orbis Terrarum (1588), shows the white buildings of the fort--and which gave it its French name, “Alger la Blanche” (El-Bahdja in Arabic)..

sp.speaker: Prospero

l.hi: O, was she so? I must

sp.l: Once in a month recount what thou hast been,
Which thou forget'st. This damn'd witch Sycorax,
For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible
To enter human hearing, from Argier,
Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did
They would not take her life. Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child
And here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave,
As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant;
And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate
To act her earthy and abhorr'd commands,
Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,
By help of her more potent ministers
And in her most unmitigable rage,
Into a cloven pine; within which rift
Imprison'd thou didst painfully remain
A dozen years; within which space she died
And left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groans
As fast as mill-wheels strikeDenoting how frequently a millwheel blade would strike the water. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest). Then was this island--
Save for the son that she did litter here,
A freckled whelp hag-born--not honour'd with
A human shape.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban
Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st
What torment I did find thee in; thy groans
Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
Of ever angry bears: it was a torment
To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax
Could not again undo: it was mine art,
When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape
The pine and let thee out.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak
And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: I will be correspondent to command
And do my spiriting gently.

sp.speaker: Prospero

l.hi: Do so, and after two days

sp.l: I will discharge thee.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject

To no sight but thine and mine, invisibleHere, Prospero hands Ariel a robe that represents a sea-nymph. Whenever the audience later sees Ariel in this robe, they are to assume that he is invisible to every other character on stage save Prospero. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest)
To every eyeball else. Go take this shape
And hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!
AwakeAriel exits the stage. He now speaks to Miranda., dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well;
Awake!

sp.speaker: Miranda

l.hi: The strangeness of your story put

sp.l: HeavinessMiranda is unaware that her father put her to sleep. in me.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: We'll visit Caliban Caliban is a complex character. He is described as a misshapen creature, described as a 'monster' 'not honored with a human shape.' He is treated as an inferior by the humans in the play. The image here, sourced from Wikimedia Commons, is an 18th century etching of Caliban by John Hamilton Mortimer (MET, 62.602.163). my slave, who never
Yields us kind answer.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: I do not love to look on.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: We cannot miss him: he does make our fire,
Fetch in our wood and serves in offices
That profit us. What, ho! slave! Caliban!
Thou earth, thou! speak.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Within There's wood enough within.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Come forth, I say! there's other business for thee:
Come, thou tortoise! when?
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,
Hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: My lord it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself
Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd
With raven's feather from unwholesome fen
Drop on you both! A blowWarm damp air carrying airborne diseases, according to the Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest. on ye
And blister you all o'er!

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps,
Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath upStop your breath (OED v).; urchins
Shall, for that vast of night that they may work,
All exercise on thee; thou shalt be pinch'd
As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging
Than bees that made 'em.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother,
Which thou takest from me. When thou camest first,
Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me
Water with berries in't, and teach me how
To name the bigger light, and how the less,
That burn by day and night: and then I loved thee
And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle,
The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile:
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms
Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!
For I am all the subjects that you have,
Which first was mine own king: and here you styTo confine me
In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me
The rest o' the island.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Whom stripes may move, not kindness! I have used thee,
Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee
In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate

The honourWhen used to describe men, "honour" or "honor" refers to the virtues of nobility of spirit, distinctin. However, whenapplied to women--like Miranda--the word most typically refers to sexual chastity or virginity (OED 7.a) of my child.

sp.speaker: Caliban

l.hi: O ho, O ho! would't had been done!

sp.l: Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else
This isle with Calibans.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Which any print of goodness wilt not takeProspero is here using the word "print" as in "impression," but with connotations deriving from the new invention of printing.,
Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee,
Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour
One thing or other: when thou didst not, savage,
Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like
A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes
With words that made them known. But thy vile race,
Though thou didst learn, had that in't which good natures
Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
Deservedly confined into this rock,
Who hadst deserved more than a prison.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: You taught me language; and my profit on't
Is, I know how to curse. The red plague rid you
For learning me your language!

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best'You are advised to' (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest),
To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?
If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly
What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps,
Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar
That beasts shall tremble at thy din.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: I must obey: his art is of such power,
It would control my dam's god, Setebos,
and make a vassal of him.

div.stage: Re-enter Ariel, invisible, playing and singing; Ferdinand following Ariel's song.

sp.speaker: [Ariel]
sp.l: Come unto these yellow sands,
And then take hands:
Courtsied when you have and kiss'd
The wild waves whist,
Foot it featly here and there;
And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear.
Hark, hark!
sp.stage: BurthenHere, "burthen" doesn't mean burden; it is used instead in a musical sense, a bass accoompaniment (from the Middle English word "bourdon"), or perhaps the refrain of a song (OED IV.9-10) (dispersedly, within)
sp.l: Bow-wow
The watch-dogs bark!
Bow-wow
Hark, hark! I hear
The strain of strutting chanticleerA dominating rooster in a courtyard.
Cry, Cock-a-diddle-dow.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth?
It sounds no more: and sure, it waits upon
Some god o' the island. Sitting on a bank,
Weeping again the king my father's wreck,
This music crept by me upon the waters,
Allaying both their fury and my passion
With its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it,
Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone.
No, it begins again.

sp.speaker: [Ariel]
sp.l: Full fathom five thy father lies;
Of his bones are coral made;
Those are pearls that were his eyes:
Nothing of him that doth fade
But doth suffer a sea-change
Into something rich and strange.
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell
Hark! now I hear them,--Ding-dong, bell.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: The ditty does remember my drown'd father.
This is no mortal business, nor no sound
That the earth owes. I hear it now above me.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: The fringed curtains of thine eye advance
And say what thou seest yond.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,
It carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses
As we have, such. This gallant which thou seest
Was in the wreck; and, but he's something stain'd
With grief that's beauty's cankerA disease that consumes vegetation (OED) , thou mightst call him
A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows
And strays about to find 'em.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: A thing divine, for nothing natural
I ever saw so noble.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: As my soul prompts it. Spirit, fine spirit! I'll free thee
Within two days for this.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: On whom these airs attend! VouchsafeTo grant or bestow. my prayer
May know if you remain upon this island;
And that you will some good instruction give
How I may bear me here: my prime request,
Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder!
If you be maid or no?

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: But certainly a maid.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I am the best of them that speak this speech,
Were I but where 'tis spoken.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders
To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me;
And that he does I weep: myself am Naples,
Who with mine eyes, never since at ebbAt low tide, beheld
The king my father wreck'd.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan
And his brave son being twain.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: The Duke of Milan
And his more braver daughter could control thee,
If now 'twere fit to do't. At the first sight
They have changed eyes. Delicate Ariel,
I'll set thee free for this.
I fear you have done yourself some wrong: a word.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Why speaks my father so ungently? This
Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first
That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father
To be inclined my way!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you
The queen of Naples.

sp.speaker: Prospero

l.hi: SoftTo kindly ask for silence (OED adv.), sir! one word more.

sp.l: They are both in either's powers; but this swift business
I must uneasy make, lest too light winning
Make the prize light.

l.hi: One word more; I charge thee

sp.l: That thou attend me: thou dost here usurp
The name thou owest notProspero accuses Ferdinand of "usurping" his father's position as king by claiming that he will make Miranda "queen of Naples".; and hast put thyself
Upon this island as a spy, to win it
From me, the lord on't.

l.hi: No, as I am a man.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple:
If the ill spirit have so fair a house,
Good things will strive to dwell with't.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Speak not you for him; he's a traitor. Come;
I'll manacle thy neck and feet together:
Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall be
The fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husks
Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I will resist such entertainment till
Mine enemy has more power.

stage.ref: Draws, and is charmed from moving
stage.note: Ferdinand draws his sword. Prospero casts a spell to transfix Ferdinand while neither he nor Miranda are aware of this.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Make not too rash a trial of him, for
He's gentle and not fearful.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor;
Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience
Is so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward,
For I can here disarm thee with this stick
And make thy weapon drop.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Hence! hang not on my garments.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: I'll be his suretyAccording to the OED, a surety in this sense is "a person who is liable for the default or misconduct of another, or for ensuring the performance of some act on another's part, such as payment of a debt or appearance in court" (surety n. 2a)..

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What!
An advocate for an imposter! hush!
Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,
Having seen but him and Caliban: foolish wench!
To the most of men this is a Caliban
And they to him are angels.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: Are then most humble; I have no ambition
To see a goodlier man.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thy nerves are in their infancy again
And have no vigour in them.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,
The wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats,
To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,
Might I but through my prison once a day
Behold this maid: all corners else o' the earth
Let liberty make use of; space enough
Have I in such a prison.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Thou hast done well, fine Ariel! [To Ferdinand] Follow me.
Harkcalling to attention, to listen, to harken to what thou else shalt do me.

sp.speaker: Miranda
sp.l: My father's of a better nature, sir,
Than he appears by speech: this is unwontedUnusual
Which now came from him.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: As mountain winds: but then exactly do
All points of my command.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Come, follow.

div.head: Scene I. Another part of the island.
div.stage: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: BeseechTo plead or beg with great earnest (OED v. 2a) you, sir, be merry; you have cause,
So have we all, of joy; for our escape
Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe
Is common; every day some sailor's wife,
The masters of some merchant and the merchant
Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle,
I mean our preservation, few in millions
Can speak like us: then wisely, good sir, weigh
Our sorrow with our comfort.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: PritheeA synonym for the word Beseech. An archaic form of 'I pray thee' (OED)., peace.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: He receives comfort like cold porridge.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: The visitor will not give him o'er so.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Look he's winding up the watch of his wit;
by and by it will strike.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Sir,--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: One: tell.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: When every grief is entertain'd
that's offer'd, Comes to the entertainer--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: A dollar According to the OED, a dollar is the English word for the thaler, a German coin of varying value used from the 16th century. The image here, sourced from "Wikimedia Commons", shows a thaler..

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: DolourSorrow or grief (OED). Gonzalo is playing along with Sebastian's jesting. comes to him, indeed: you have spoken truer than you purposed.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Therefore, my lord,--

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: FieA Middle English expression of disgust, used to refer to children to "excite shame for some unbecoming action" (OED)., what a spendthriftSomeone who irresponsibly squanders his income. (OED 2) is he of his tongue!

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: I prithee, spare.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Well, I have done: but yet,--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: He will be talking.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager,
first begins to crow?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: The old cock.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: The cockerel.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Done. The wager?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: A laughter.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: A match!

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: Though this island seem to be desert,--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! So, you're paid.

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible,--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Yet,--

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: Yet,--

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: He could not miss't.

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: It must needs be of subtle, tender and delicate temperance.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Temperance was a delicate wench.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly delivered.

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: As if it had lungs and rotten ones.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fenSmelly marsh lands..

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Here is everything advantageous to life.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: True; save means to live.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Of that there's none, or little.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: The ground indeed is tawny.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: With an eye of green in't.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: He misses not much.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed almost beyond credit,--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: As many vouched rarities are.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched
in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and
glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt
water.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: If but one of his pockets could speak, would
it not say he lies?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as
when we put them on first in AfricAn Old English form of Africa (OED)., at the marriage

of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of TunisTunis is the capital city in Tunisia, a country in North Africa. The northern coast of the country, where Tunis is, is on the Mediterranean Sea..

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in
our return.

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: Tunis was never graced before with such a
Paragon to their Queen.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Not since widow DidoIn Greek mythology, Dido, a widow, falls in love with Aeneas and kills herself after he leaves her to go and build the city of Rome (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest).'s time.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow
in? widow Dido!

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too?
Good Lord, how you take it!

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: 'Widow Dido' said you? you make me study of that:

she was of CarthageCarthage and Tunis weren't the same city, but later on, Carthage was usurped, and Tunis took it's place as the main powerful state of the region. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest), not of Tunis.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.

sp.speaker: Adrian
sp.l: Carthage?

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I assure you, Carthage.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: His word is more than the miraculous harp Sebastian is referring to the harp that Amphion, son of Zeus is known to have used when constructing the walls of Thebes, a city in Boeotia, Greece. (The Arden Shakespeare edition of The Tempest); he hath raised the wall and houses too.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: What impossible matter will he make easy next?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I think he will carry this island home in
his pocket and give it his son for an apple.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea,
bring forth more islands.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Why, in good time.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now
as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage
of your daughter, who is now queen.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: And the rarest that e'er came there.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: O, widow Dido! ay, widow Dido.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the
first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: That sort was well fished for.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: You cram these words into mine ears against
The stomach of my sense. Would I had never
Married my daughter there! for, coming thence,
My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,
Who is so far from Italy removed
I ne'er again shall see her. O thou mine heir

Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fishThis phrase may be a reference to the sea creatures that were often depicted in the oceans of early modern maps. While in earlier periods, when little was known about the shapes of land masses, these sea creatures were signs of danger and the unknown; however, by the late 16th and 17th centuries, sea travel and exploration was on the rise, and this led to more and more complete maps. As the unknown declined, so too did representationos of sea monsters. They transitioned into less threatening and more whimsical fish or whales, and in the modern world, they all but disappeared cartographically. To learn more about the "strange fish" of early modern cartography, see "Mapping the Oceans: How Cartographers Saw the World in the Age of Discovery" at Lapham's Quarterly.
Hath made his meal on thee?

sp.speaker: Francisco
sp.l: Sir, he may live:
I saw him beat the surges under him,
And ride upon their backs; he trod the water,
Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted

The surge most swolnAccording to the OED (IV. 5a), breasted in this sense means "To move forwards directly into, to confront head-on; to climb." Francisco means to say that he witnessed Ferdinand survive contact with a large wave. that met him; his bold head
'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd
Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd,
As stooping to relieve him: I not doubt
He came alive to land.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: No, no, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,
That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,
But rather lose her to an African;
Where she at least is banish'd from your eye,
Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Prithee, peace.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise
By all of us, and the fair soul herself
Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at
Which end o' the beam should bow. We have lost your son,
I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples have
More widows in them of this business' making
Than we bring men to comfort them:
The fault's your own.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: So is the dear'st o' the loss.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: My lord Sebastian,
The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness
And time to speak it in: you rub the sore,
When you should bring the plaster.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: And most chirurgeonly"Chirurgeon" is an older spelling of "surgeon" (OED)..

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: It is foul weather in us all, good sir,
When you are cloudy.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Foul weather?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Very foul.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Had I plantationThe word "plantation" is significant in the early modern period, as it refers to colonization; Gonzalo imagines his dominion over the island. It also has another sense, meaning a site of planting, which Antonio plays on in the next line. of this isle, my lord,--

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: He'ld sow't with nettle-seed.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Or docks, or mallows.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: And were the king on't, what would I do?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: 'scape being drunk for want of wine.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I' the commonwealth I would by contraries
Execute all things; for no kind of traffic
Would I admit; no name of magistrate;
Letters should not be known; riches, poverty,
And use of service, none; contract, succession,
Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none;
No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil;
No occupation; all men idle, all;
And women too, but innocent and pure;
No sovereignty;--

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Yet he would be king on't.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo

l.ref: All things in common nature should produce
l.note: Gonzalo seems to be suggesting that the trappings of modern civilization lead to corruptiono and want. He imagines a pure, idyllic place without violence, commerce, or vice.

sp.l: Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony,
Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,
Would I not have; but nature should bring forth,
Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance,
To feed my innocent people.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: No marrying 'mong his subjects?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: None, man; all idle: whores and knavesDishonorable men.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I would with such perfection govern, sir,
To excel the golden age.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: God save his majesty!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Long live Gonzalo!

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: And,--do you mark me, sir?

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: I do well believe your highness; and did it to
minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of
such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use
to laugh at nothing.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: 'Twas you we laughed at.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing
to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: What a blow was there given!

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: An it had not fallen flat-long.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would
lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue
in it five weeks without changing.

div.stage: Enter Ariel, invisible, playing solemn music

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: We would so, and then go a bat-fowlingA way of catching birds at night by flashing them with a bright light, so as to disorient them (OED)..

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my
discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I
am very heavyAriel is working magic to put them to sleep.?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Go sleep, and hear us.

div.stage: All sleep except Alonso, Sebastian, and Antonio

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes Would,
with themselves, shut up my thoughts:
I find They are inclined to do so.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Please you, sir,
Do not omit the heavy offer of it:
It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth,
It is a comforter.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: We two, my lord,
Will guard your person while you take your rest,
And watch your safety.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Thank you. Wondrous heavy.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: It is the quality o' the climate.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Why
Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not
Myself disposed to sleep.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Nor I; my spirits are nimble.
They fell together all, as by consent;
They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might,
Worthy Sebastian? O, what might?--No more:--
And yet me thinks I see it in thy face,
What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, and
My strong imagination sees a crown
Dropping upon thy head.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: What, art thou waking?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Do you not hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I do; and surely
It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st
Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
This is a strange repose, to be asleep
With eyes wide open; standing, speaking, moving,
And yet so fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Noble Sebastian,
Thou let'st thy fortune sleep--die, rather; wink'st
Whiles thou art waking.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Thou dost snore distinctly;
There's meaning in thy snores.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: I am more serious than my custom: you
Must be so too, if heed me; which to do
Trebles thee o'er.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Well, I am standing water.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: I'll teach you how to flow.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Do so: to ebb
Hereditary slothSebastian says that he is naturally slothful or slow; he is naturally driven to ebb, and not to flow. instructs me.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: O,
If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
Whiles thus you mock it! how, in stripping it,
You more invest it! Ebbing men, indeed,
Most often do so near the bottom run
By their own fear or sloth.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Prithee, say on:
The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
A matter from thee, and a birth indeed
Which throes thee much to yield.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Thus, sir:
Although this lord of weak remembrance, this,
Who shall be of as little memory
When he is earth'd, hath here almost persuade,--
For he's a spirit of persuasion, only
Professes to persuade,--the king his son's alive,
'Tis as impossible that he's undrown'd
And he that sleeps here swims.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I have no hope
That he's undrown'd.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: O, out of that 'no hope'
What great hope have you! no hope that way is
Another way so high a hope that even
Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond,
But doubt discovery there. Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drown'd?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Then, tell me,
Who's the next heir of Naples?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Claribel.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: She that is queen of Tunis; she that dwells
Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples
Can have no note, unless the sun were post--
The man i' the moon's too slow--till new-born chins
Be rough and razorable; she that--from whom?
We all were sea-swallow'd, though some cast again,
And by that destiny to perform an act
Whereof what's past is prologue, what to come
In yours and my discharge.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: What stuff is this! how say you?
'Tis true, my brother's daughter's queen of Tunis;
So is she heir of Naples; 'twixt which regions
There is some space.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: A space whose every cubit
Seems to cry out, 'How shall that Claribel
Measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis,
And let Sebastian wake.' Say, this were death
That now hath seized them; why, they were no worse
Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that sleeps; lords that can prateIrrelevant chatter
As amply and unnecessarily
As this Gonzalo; I myself could make
A choughA chatterer of as deep chat. O, that you bore
The mind that I do! what a sleep were this
For your advancement! Do you understand me?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Methinks I do.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: And how does your content
Tender your own good fortune?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: I remember
You did supplant your brother Prospero.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: True:
And look how well my garments sit upon me;
Much featerA better fit than before: my brother's servants
Were then my fellows; now they are my men.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: But, for your conscience?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Ay, sir; where lies that? if 'twere a kibeAccording to the OED 1a., a kibe is a Middle English word meaning "A chapped or ulcerated chilblain, esp. one on the heel." A chilblain is a red, rough, patchy area of skin.,
'Twould put me to my slipper: but I feel not
This deity in my bosom: twenty consciences,
That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they
And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother,
No better than the earth he lies upon,
If he were that which now he's like, that's dead;
Whom I, with this obedient steel, three inches of it,
Can lay to bed for ever; whiles you, doing thus,
To the perpetual wink for aye might put
This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who
Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest,
They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk;
They'll tell the clock to any business that
We say befits the hour.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Thy case, dear friend,
Shall be my precedent; as thou got'st Milan,
I'll come by Naples. Draw thy sword: one stroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest;
And I the king shall love thee.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Draw together;
And when I rear my hand, do you the like,
To fall it on Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: O, but one word.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: My master through his art foresees the danger
That you, his friend, are in; and sends me forth--
For else his project dies--to keep them living.
While you here do snoring lie,
Open-eyed conspiracy
His time doth take.
If of life you keep a care,
Shake off slumber, and beware:
Awake, awake!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Then let us both be sudden.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Now, good angels Preserve the king.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Why, how now? ho, awake! Why are you drawn?
Wherefore this ghastly looking?

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Whiles we stood here securing your repose,
Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
Like bulls, or rather lions: did't not wake you?
It struck mine ear most terribly.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: I heard nothing.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: O, 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear,
To make an earthquake! sure, it was the roar
Of a whole herd of lions.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Heard you this, Gonzalo?

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Upon mine honour, sir, I heard a humming,
(And that a strange one too) which did awake me:
I shaked you, sir, and cried: as mine eyes open'd,
I saw their weapons drawn: there was a noise,
That's verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard,
Or that we quit this place; let's draw our weapons.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Lead off this ground; and let's make further search
For my poor son.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Heavens keep him from these beasts!
For he is, sure, i' the island.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Lead away.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Prospero my lord shall know what I have done:
So, king, go safely on to seek thy son.

div.head: Scene II. Another part of the island.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Tell not me; when the butt is out, we will drink
water; not a drop before: therefore bear up, and
board 'em. Servant-monster, drink to me.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Servant-monster! the folly of this island! They
say there's but five upon this isle: we are three
of them; if th' other two be brained like us, the
state tottersAn unsteady or shaky movement (OED).

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee: thy eyes
are almost set in thy head.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Where should they be set else? he were a brave
monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: My man-monster hath drown'd his tongue in sack:
for my part, the sea cannot drown me; I swam, ere I
could recover the shore, five and thirty leagues off
and on. By this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant,
monster, or my standardAccording to the OED, A standard is an obsolete term, referring to "a person who carries a standard, often as a permanent duty'..

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Your lieutenant, if you list; he's no standard.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: We'll not run, Monsieur Monster.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Nor go neither; but you'll lie like dogs and yet say
nothing neither.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Moon-calf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a
good moon-calf.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: How does thy honour? Let me lick thy shoe.
I'll not serve him; he's not valiant.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Thou liest, most ignorant monster: I am in case to

justle a constableTrinculo claims that he is ready to fight a constable, who is the chief officer of the court (OED).. Why, thou deboshedA variant of the term debauched--over-indulging in sensual pleasures, including drinking (OED). fish thou,
was there ever man a coward that hath drunk so much
sack as I to-day? Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie,
being but half a fish and half a monster?

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Lo, how he mocks me! wilt thou let him, my lord?

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: 'Lord' quoth he! That a monster should be such a natural!

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Lo, lo, again! bite him to death, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head: if you
prove a mutineer,--the next tree! The poor monster's
my subject and he shall not suffer indignity.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleased to
hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Marry, will I kneel and repeat it; I will stand,
and so shall Trinculo.

div.stage: Enter Ariel, invisible Ariel is accompanied by his fellow spirits as he sings his song.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, a
sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou: I would my
valiant master would destroy thee! I do not lie.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in's tale, by
this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Why, I said nothing.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: I say, by sorcery he got this isle;
From me he got it. if thy greatness will
Revenge it on him,--for I know thou darest,
But this thing dare not,--

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: That's most certain.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Thou shalt be lord of it and I'll serve thee.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: How now shall this be compassed?
Canst thou bring me to the party?

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Yea, yea, my lord: I'll yield him thee asleep,
Where thou mayst knock a nail into his bead.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Thou liest; thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: What a pied ninny"Pied" refers to the many-colored or mixed-up costume a jester would wear. A "ninny" is a simpleton.'s this! Thou scurvy patch!
I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows
And take his bottle from him: when that's gone
He shall drink nought but brineSalty sea water.; for I'll not show him
Where the quick freshes are.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Trinculo, run into no further danger:
interrupt the monster one word further, and,
by this hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors
and make a stock-fish of thee.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Why, what did I? I did nothing. I'll go farther
off.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Didst thou not say he lied?

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Do I so? take thou that.
As you like this, give me the lie another time.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: I did not give the lie. Out o' your
wits and bearing too? A poxAn exclamation of frustration or anger; Trinculo wishes the pox--syphillis--upon Stephano's drinking. (OED). o' your bottle!
this can sack and drinking do. A murraina deadly infectious disease (OED). on
your monster, and the devil take your fingers!

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Now, forward with your tale. Prithee, stand farther
off.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Beat him enough: after a little time
I'll beat him too.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Stand farther. Come, proceed.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Why, as I told thee, 'tis a custom with him,
I' th' afternoon to sleep: there thou mayst brain him,
Having first seized his books, or with a log
Batter his skull, or paunchTo stab or wound in the stomach (OED). him with a stake,
Or cut his wezandThe throat or windpipe. with thy knife. Remember
First to possess his books; for without them
He's but a sot, as I am, nor hath not
One spirit to command: they all do hate him
As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.
He has brave utensils,--for so he calls them--
Which when he has a house, he'll deck withal
And that most deeply to consider is
The beauty of his daughter; he himself
Calls her a nonpareilincomparable: I never saw a woman,
But only Sycorax my dam and she;
But she as far surpasseth Sycorax
As great'st does least.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Is it so brave a lass?

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Ay, lord; she will become thy bed, I warrant.
And bring thee forth brave brood.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Monster, I will kill this man: his daughter and I
will be king and queen--save our graces!--and
Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys. Dost thou
like the plot, Trinculo?

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Give me thy hand: I am sorry I beat thee; but,
while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Within this half hour will he be asleep:
Wilt thou destroy him then?

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Ay, on mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: This will I tell my master.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Thou makest me merry; I am full of pleasure:
Let us be jocund: will you troll the catch
You taught me but while-ere?

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any
reason. Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.
Flout 'em and scout 'em
And scout 'em and flout 'em
Thought is free.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: That's not the tune.

div.stage: Ariel plays the tune on a tabour and pipe

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: What is this same?

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: This is the tune of our catch, played by the picture
of Nobody.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness:
if thou beest a devil, take't as thou list.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: O, forgive me my sins!

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: He that dies pays all debts: I defy thee. Mercy upon us!

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Art thou afeard?

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: No, monster, not I.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: Be not afeardThe following speech by Caliban is one of the most famous and studied passages of the play. Caliban who had lived his entire life on the island feels a deeper connection to its beauty and richness.; the isle is full of noises,
Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight and hurt not.
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments
Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices
That, if I then had waked after long sleep,
Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming,
The clouds methought would open and show riches
Ready to drop upon me that, when I waked,
I cried to dream again.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall
have my music for nothing.

sp.speaker: Caliban
sp.l: When Prospero is destroyed.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: That shall be by and by: I remember the story.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: The sound is going away; let's follow it, and
after do our work.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Lead, monster; we'll follow. I would I could see
this tabourer; he lays it on.

sp.speaker: Trinculo
sp.l: Wilt come? I'll follow, Stephano.

div.head: Scene III. Another part of the island.
div.stage: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: My old bones ache: here's a maze trod indeed
Through forth-rights and meanders! By your patience,
I needs must rest me.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Old lord, I cannot blame thee,
Who am myself attach'd with weariness,
To the dulling of my spirits: sit down, and rest.
Even here I will put off my hope and keep it
No longer for my flatterer: he is drown'd
Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks
Our frustrate search on land. Well, let him go.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Aside to Sebastian I am right glad that he's so out of hope.
Do not, for one repulse, forego the purpose
That you resolved to effect.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Aside to Antonio The next advantage
Will we take throughly.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Aside to Sebastian Let it be to-night;
For, now they are oppress'd with travel, they
Will not, nor cannot, use such vigilance
As when they are fresh.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: Aside to Antonio I say, to-night: no more.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Marvellous sweet music!

div.stage: Enter Prospero above In this scene, the upper stage allows Prospero's character secretly observe the plot transpiring below on the main stage., invisible. Enter several strange Shapes, bringing in a banquet; they dance about it with gentle actions of salutation; and, inviting the King, &c. to eat, they depart

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: A living drolleryA comical entertainment in the form of a puppet-show (OED 2.a). Now I will believe
That there are unicorns, that in Arabia
There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix
At this hour reigning there.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: I'll believe both;
And what does else want creditlacking in credibility, come to me,
And I'll be sworn 'tis true: travellers ne'er did lie,
Though fools at home condemn 'em.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: If in Naples
I should report this now, would they believe me?
If I should say, I saw such islanders--
For, certesAn archaic form of the term meaning certainly, assuredly (OED)., these are people of the island--
Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet, note,
Their manners are more gentle-kind than of
Our human generation you shall find
Many, nay, almost any.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Aside Honest lord,
Thou hast said well; for some of you there present
Are worse than devils.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: I cannot too much muse
Such shapes, such gesture and such sound, expressing,
Although they want the use of tongue, a kind
Of excellent dumb discourse.

sp.speaker: Prospero
sp.l: Aside Praise in departing.

sp.speaker: Francisco
sp.l: They vanish'd strangely.

sp.speaker: Sebastian
sp.l: No matter, since
They have left their viands behind; for we have stomachs.
Will't please you taste of what is here?

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Gonzalo
sp.l: Faith, sir, you need not fear. When we were boys,
Who would believe that there were mountaineers

Dew-lapp'd like bullsGonzalo describes the physical attributes of the indigenous people living on the island, commenting that their necks have a similar folding of excessive loose skin that hangs from the throats of cattle (OED)., whose throats had hanging at 'em
Wallets of flesh? or that there were such men
Whose heads stood in their breasts? which now we find
Each putter-out of five for one will bring us
Good warrant of.

sp.speaker: Alonso
sp.l: I will stand to and feed,
Although my last: no matter, since I feel
The best is past. Brother, my lord the duke,
Stand to and do as we.

div.stage: Thunder and lightning. Enter Ariel, like a harpy Ariel appears in the form of a harpy, a greedy and fearsome mythological creature that metes out divine justice and vengeance. Harpies have the head and body of a woman and the wings and claws of a bird. Ariel is imagined as wreaking the 'divine' vengeance of Prospero. This annotation and image are sourced from World History Encyclopedia. The image here, also from the World History Encyclopedia, is an illustration of the harpy from Ulisse Aldrovandi's Monstrorum Historia, Bologna, 1642.; claps his wings upon the table; and, with a quaint device, the banquet vanishes

sp.speaker: Ariel
sp.l: You are three men of sin, whom Destiny,
That hath to instrument this lower world
And what is in't, the never-surfeitedThe insatiable nature of the sea. sea
Hath caused to belch up you; and on this island
Where man doth not inhabit; you 'mongst men
Being most unfit to live. I have made you mad;
And even with such-like valour men hang and drown
Their proper selves.
You fools! I and my fellows
Are ministers of Fate: the elements,
Of whom your swords are temper'd, may as well
Wound the loud winds, or with bemock'd-at stabs
Kill the still-closing waters, as diminish
One dowleThe OED define dowl as "One of the filaments of fibres of a feather' that's in my plume: my fellow-ministers
Are like invulnerable. If you could hurt,
Your swords are now too massy for your strengths
And will not be uplifted. But remember--
For that's my business to you--that you three
From Milan did supplant good Prospero;

Some vanity of mine art
Prospero plans to use his magic to create the fantastic entertainment of a masque for the young couple. According to material hosted by the Royal Historic Palaces, masques were elaborate court entertainments staged for and often by nobility. They involved a variety of performance types--ballet, opera, music, and theater--combined in a highly visual and stylized manner. By the early 17th century, when Shakespeare wrote and performed The Tempest, they had become highly elaborate. The Royal Banqueting House, designed by Inigo Jones and completed in 1622, was purpose-built for the staging of masques. The most popular early court masques were developed by Jones in partnership with Ben Jonson.
Thematically, masques represented and reinforced the divinity of the monarchy and symbolized a world of order in opposition to the baseness and disorder that reigned before the emergence of the Stuart Court. In The Tempest, Prospero conjures the masque as a gift for the young couple, Miranda and Ferdinand, who will marry upon their return to Naples and return order to the throne. This masque, like all masques, then, is a statement of political power.
